I am from Michigan. I've had minor frostbite. When yor skin feels numb at first and it turns very White. Then it feels like there's no blood getting to the part of your body th at has frostbite. Then, your affected skin starts to feel extremely hot.
You usually get frostbite in your hands, feet, ears and face first. Then it will spread to the rest of your body.
If frostbite gets severe enough, or you don't warm up soon enough, your cells in the affected area could die and have to be amputated!
If you don't warm your body up as soon as possible after getting frostbite, it can lead to more severe frostbite and become a medical emergency! Or, worse yet, it can lead to hypothermia. That is much worse! Hypothermia is automatically a life threatening, medical emergency! You have no choice but to get to the hospital emergency room as soon as possible or you could die!!!

I’ve experienced the “hot rush” before when looking for a job in the winter. I was 20yrs old and needed work badly. I would ride my bike in the winter applying at stores and such.

I would layer up pretty good but one day it got bitterly cold and super windy on my ride back home. I was getting super cold and about halfway home I started to get really sweaty and hot. I almost wanted to stop and undo my scarf and unzip my jacket. I thought it was because I was pushing my self but I actually felt like I was getting really hot. I knew that it had to be the onset of hypothermia and pushed myself harder to get home as I was on the final stretch.

Got home and as soon as I got into the apartment building I felt a rush of coldness sweep over me, then followed by the burning hot sensation or actual heat from entering a heated environment.

I felt super numb and tingly. Went to take a shower and had to use luke warm water to avoid burning my skin. Never again have I ever exposed myself to the cold for that long. I’m lucky I had no long term effects from this.
